Props.Text: $$SERVER$:$WELCOME_TO_Death-Valley
$$SERVER$:$SERVER_SLOGAN
Q: What page is this showing on?
A: Just a demo server info page provided by the Ark-Nucleus mod.
This is just a small representation of what kind of pages can be setup using the Ark-Nucleus JSON Editor.
Q: Can I disable this for my server?
A: Yes, Go to Installed Mods -> Ark Nucleus ->Server Settings
As majority of things is optional in Ark-Nucleus so is the Server Info Page. You don't see use for it? Disable it!
Q: Who can edit this page?
A: Only Admins can edit this page.
If you are in the admin mode, you will see an EDIT button in the upper right corner.
Death-Valley FAQ!!!
Death-Valley Lore FAQ
Q: WHAT IS DEATH‑VALLEY?

A: Death‑Valley began like any other Ark — a shard of a broken world drifting in the void, a place to survive, to build, to hope. But for those who found it, it became something more. When life outside offered no home, the Valley became one. A refuge. A promise. A world worth fighting for.
Q: WHAT WAS THE AGE OF BUILDING

A: Beneath a sky of crystal light, We rose from nothing and claimed the night. Stone to iron, beasts to friends — Our tribes built homes the stars would defend. The First Builders walked among our lands, Teaching the ways with steady hands. For 9 long years the Arks would thrive, Under the watch of the Wildcards’ eye.
Q: THE SHADOW NAMED SNAILGAMES

A: But whispers crossed the distant seas, A name carried on a windswept breeze. SnailGames — the campfires cursed — A shadow that brought the dark clouds first. Their word was law, their hearts were cold, The fate of the Arks in their hands to hold. No council heard, no pleas could stay The night they chose to take it away.
Q: THE GREAT FALL

A: On the thirtieth day of the ninth year’s end, The sky grew silent, with no light to send. The towers dimmed, the beasts cried out, As tribes fell silent, their flames burned out. Worlds we built with love and pain Were gone in an instant — nothing remained.
Q: THE FIRST BUILDERS STAND

A: The First Builders wept beside our tribes; They fought with words, they fought with time. But SnailGames held the final key And cast the worlds into the sea. The gates were closed, the Arks would die, Our homes turned dust beneath the sky.
Q: THE CRYSTAL MEMORIES
A: We gathered the shards of what had been — The crystal memories of the worlds we’d seen. We carried them into the Ascended dawn, Though the heart of the old worlds was forever gone.
Q: THE VOW OF THE SURVIVORS

A: On the thirtieth day of the ninth year’s end, The tribes remember — the scars won’t mend. SnailGames took the worlds we knew, But the tribes will rise; we’ll start anew. For every beast, for every friend, We’ll build again — until the very end.
Q: How do I contact the server admins?
A: If you need assistance or have any concerns, you can reach out to our server admins via Discord. They are here to help resolve any issues and ensure everyone has an enjoyable gaming experience.
We hope this FAQ helps address any questions you may have about our Ark game server. If you have any further inquiries, don't hesitate to ask our friendly community or server staff. Happy gaming!
Rules For Death-Valley
The listed Ruels and Guides are just some of the rules listed in discord
1. Respect thy Neighbor: Treat your fellow Survivors with courtesy and respect. No harassment, hate speech, or toxic behavior will be tolerated.
2. PvP: PvP is welcomed, but raids are sacred battles, No base may be raided without the opponent’s consent in Discord, A raid is a clash of warriors — never a one‑sided siege.

3. Cheating and Exploits: Respect is the law of the realm. All who walk these lands must treat one another with honor, Harassment, hate speech, and toxic conduct are forbidden and will be purged without mercy. We're here for fair play and a fun experience for everyone.

4. Let your structures rise with purpose: not greed. In the realm of Death-Valley, the land itself is sacred. Overgrown fortresses, reckless sprawl, and pillar corruption are forbidden, for they choke the world and weaken the flow of its power. Build with intention, and the realm will honor you.
5. Fair Play Edict: Creatures under taming are sacred. No member may harm or slay a beast in the midst of bonding. Honor the ritual or face the consequences.
6. Roleplay Encouraged: Engage in immersive roleplay if that's your style! Whether you're a lone survivor, a tribal leader, or a dino tamer, bring your character to life.
7. Community Events: Join in on server-wide events for a chance to earn rewards, make new friends, and test your skills against the challenges we throw your way.

8. Let it be known: Those who twist the world through cheats, exploits, or forbidden tools break the sacred balance. Such actions will be met with immediate judgment. This realm thrives on fair combat and true challenge.
The Codex Of Death-Valley Reborn V1.20

I didn’t step into ARK because I wanted an adventure. I stepped into it because real life had already taken everything from me. Back then, my partner and I were living out of a battered camper trailer — the kind that creaks when the wind hits it and leaks when the rain decides to test you. We didn’t have an address, We didn’t have a plan, Most days, we didn’t even have a sense of tomorrow. Nights were the worst, The cold crawled in through the thin walls, and the silence pressed down like a weight I couldn’t lift. Every sunrise felt like a reminder that we were still drifting, still nowhere, still invisible to the world. I didn’t know it then, but I was slipping, Not just in life — inside myself, And then one day, a voice from my past reached out. An old friend, Someone who remembered me from a life that felt like it belonged to someone else. He said, “Come. I’ll show you a land where dinos roam and dreams can stand.” I didn’t understand what he meant. But when you’re drowning, even a strange rope looks like salvation. So I grabbed it. He showed me a world of mountains and rivers, a place wild enough to swallow you whole and gentle enough to give you a second chance. That world was ARK: Survival Evolved. And for the first time in a long time, I felt something I hadn’t felt in the real world: Possibility. In ARK, no one could take my home away, No landlord, No system, No circumstance. If I built something, it stayed, If I fought for something, it mattered, If I dreamed of something, I could make it real. That was the beginning of everything.

Raasclark and the Guides of the Old World
I didn’t know how to survive in ARK at first, Not really, I was lost in the game the same way I was lost in life. So I searched for help — not knowing what I was really searching for — and I found a streamer named Raasclark. He never knew it, but his videos became my lifeline. His calm explanations, his guides, his voice — they steadied me in a way nothing else did at the time. Through him, I learned how to tame, how to build, how to survive, how to dream again. With his unseen guidance, Death‑Valley (ASE) was born. My partner joined me, and together we built a home that reached for the sky — a home no storm could tear down, no landlord could take, no world could deny us. For the first time in years, I felt like I belonged somewhere. This wasn’t just the beginning of a server. It was the beginning of a world, A community, A legacy. And I had no idea how much it would one day cost… or how much it would one day give back.

Chapter Two — The Rise of Death‑Valley When a home became a world, and a world became a family.
When I first stepped into ARK, I wasn’t trying to build anything big. I wasn’t dreaming of cities or communities or legacies. I just wanted a place where the ground didn’t disappear under my feet. At the start, it was just me and my partner —  two people who had lost almost everything in the real world, trying to build something that couldn’t be taken from us. We started small, A few walls, A fire, A roof that didn’t leak when it rained, But something strange happened. Every stone we placed felt like a heartbeat, Every tame felt like a promise, Every sunrise over the Valley  felt like a reminder that maybe — just maybe — we could build a life again, And then the Valley grew. Not because we planned it, Not because we advertised it. Not because we were trying to make something big. It grew because people like us — wanderers, drifters, survivors — started showing up. At first, it was one or two. Then a handful, Then more, Some were lost, Some were curious, Some were running from worlds that had failed them. Some were just looking for a place where they didn’t have to fight alone. And somehow, they found us. They found Death‑Valley. I didn’t name it that because it sounded cool. I named it that because it was honest. We had died a lot, In the game, In life. In ways that didn’t leave scars on the skin but carved deep into the soul. But every time we died, we came back, Every time we fell, we rebuilt. Every time the world tried to bury us, we clawed our way out. Death‑Valley wasn’t a warning, It was a declaration. We die, but we rise, And the Valley rose with us. Huts became houses. Houses became bases. Bases became districts. Districts became a city. A real one — not just pixels and code, but a place that felt alive. We built markets, outposts, skybridges, sanctuaries. We forged alliances. We shared resources. We defended each other from the wilds. We laughed together. We fought together. We survived together. And somewhere along the way, without planning it, without even noticing it at first… We became a family. Not the kind you’re born into. The kind you build. The kind you choose. The kind that chooses you back. For a moment — a long, beautiful moment — it felt like nothing could ever break what we had built. But worlds built on hope are always the ones the storm seeks first. And one day… the sky darkened.

The Last Day of Death‑Valley ASE, Truth, heartbreak, and the lie we were told.
September 29th, 2023.
I didn’t know it then, but that date would carve itself into me deeper than any scar the real world ever left. It was the day the sky fell — not just in ARK, but in my chest. To understand what happened, you have to understand the universe we lived beside. The official network wasn’t just big. It was a titan — a galaxy of over 30,000 Arks, each sealed off by platform walls long before crossplay ever existed, Every server had its own tribes, its own wars, its own legends. A multiverse of worlds, each with a lifetime inside it, And then there was the unofficial realm — the wild frontier, By 2022 and 2023, there were over 24,000 independent servers. And this was only xbox, Death‑Valley was four of them. Small, Unassuming, Unprotected, But alive. We weren’t part of the official cluster, but we lived in its shadow, Our rates were tied to theirs —  when the official network surged, we surged, When it strained, we felt the tremors. We were a tiny world orbiting a giant, And then the whispers started. Rumors drifted across Discords like smoke from a dying fire, Players spoke in hushed tones. People panicked, A name rode the cold wind... Wildcard, At least… that’s what we were told. The first reports claimed that Wildcard themselves were shutting everything down. That they had fired the rockets, That they had collapsed the Arks, That they had chosen to erase a decade of worlds. And that lie hit harder than any dino ever could, Because Wildcard wasn’t just a studio to me. They were the creators who gave me a home when I had none, They were the reason Death‑Valley existed at all. They were the reason I survived nights when the real world felt too heavy, To believe they had done this… it shattered something inside me. I didn’t feel hope, I didn’t feel resolve, I didn’t feel anger at first. I felt heartbreak — the kind that makes your chest ache, I felt rage — a fire that burned hotter than any wyvern’s breath. I felt betrayal — sharp and cold, And then the night came. The sky turned black — not the darkness of night, But the darkness of a world losing its heartbeat, Across the entire official network, all 30,000 Arks flickered. Obelisks dimmed, Creatures cried out, Tribes gathered on rooftops, staring at the heavens like they were waiting  for an answer that would never come. And then… Silence, The official network collapsed, Not slowly, Not piece by piece, All at once — like a galaxy blinking out, And even though Death‑Valley was unofficial, the shockwave hit us like a meteor, Our rates died, Our stability died, Our worlds died with them. I woke up to find the entire cluster gone. Not corrupted, Not damaged, GONE. Four worlds erased, Four homes extinguished, Four stories swallowed by the void, But the truth — the real truth — didn’t surface until later. The Elder Tribes, the players with tek‑sight and long memories, uncovered what really happened. The rockets that collapsed the Arks were not fired by Wildcard. They were fired by SnailGames — the corporation that owned Wildcard, the corporation that hid behind their name, the corporation that let the  world blame the wrong people, Wildcard wasn’t the villain, They never were, They were survivors too — forced to watch their worlds burn, And SnailGames… they were the ones who lit the match. That was the truth behind the fall, The truth behind the heartbreak, The truth behind the rage, The truth that would one day fuel the rebirth of Death‑Valley.

Ascension (2023–2024) Where vengeance forged the path… and family changed the destination.
When ASE fell, something inside me fell with it, I wasn’t ready to forgive, I wasn’t ready to heal, I wasn’t ready to start over. So when ARK: Survival Ascended launched on October 26th 2023 I didn’t step into it with hope, I stepped into it with a mission, ASA wasn’t a new beginning for me, It was a battlefield, A place where I could rebuild my strength, gather my power, and one day strike back at the ones who destroyed Death‑Valley. I made a vow — not quietly, not gently, but with the kind of fire that only heartbreak can ignite: I would take down every boss in ASA, Map by map, Ascension by ascension, Until I reached the final arena. And when I got there, I would create a mod — a monstrous, fire‑breathing Death Snail, a titan forged from rage and justice, a creature that embodied everything SnailGames had done to us, I would face it, I would kill it, And in that victory, I would reclaim what they stole. This wasn’t rebuilding, This was war, ASA’s crashes, wipes, corrupted saves — none of it slowed me down. If anything, every bug felt like another insult thrown by the same hands that destroyed ASE. Every crash felt personal, But I pushed forward, Because vengeance has a way of keeping you moving even when hope can’t.

The War Camp of the Wanderer 
With the machine ready, the real work began, Every script I wrote taught me something new. Every config I rebuilt sharpened my understanding, Every server I launched became another step in learning how to shape a world from nothing. ASA was unstable — crashes, wipes, corrupted saves — but I didn’t care, If anything, the chaos only hardened my resolve. I rebuilt Death‑Valley with the ashes of ASE still clinging to my hands, Fresh configs, Rewritten scripts, New automation, New systems, New defenses, New fire in my chest, I wasn’t building comfort, I was building power. Because I had a plan, a furious, beautiful plan, but what happend next i wasnt ready for
The Moment Everything Changed

The Moment The Spartan Arrived, Ark Survival Ascended 
 The Island 2023 
It began like any other day. I came home, powered on my partner’s Xbox Series S, and slipped into the familiar rhythm of Ark: Survival Ascended. Hours passed in the quiet way they do when you’re gathering, building, surviving, Then my brother‑in‑law walked in. “What are you playing?” “A dinosaur game called Ark,” I told him. “I can build my own home, tame creatures, ride them. It’s Ark: Survival Ascended.” He had heard the legends of Ark: Survival Evolved — stories that had echoed so far they crossed into other games, other communities, other worlds. I didn’t think much of it. But while I kept playing, he made a decision. He bought the game, He downloaded it, He grabbed the new DLC, Bob’s Tall Tales. And before I even realized what was happening, he was staring at the server list. “What server are you on?” “Death‑Valley,” I said,  showing him the second world of Ark: Survival Ascended. He spawned in like any ordinary Bob… but he wasn’t ordinary, Not even close. Within minutes, he was beside me — moving with instinct, adapting with speed, surviving with a confidence that didn’t belong to a beginner. It felt like there were suddenly three of me. My partner didn’t play much, so really it was just the two of us —  but the tribe now had three names, and the search for a new home began.

Sparda’s Beach Tower 
 We walked the coastline for what felt like weeks, searching for a place that felt right. Then he saw it. Crystal‑blue water, Sharks circling in the depths, A tiny island connected to the mainland by a thin strip of sand and stone, We swam for it. The megalodon smelled us before we were halfway across, I warned him — “The meg is coming” — but it was too late for me. I fell to the beast, Sparda didn’t, He made it to shore, kept moving, and found the perfect place to build a small shelter. At least… that’s what it started as, Days passed, The small box grew taller, Wider, Stronger. Until, five days later,  Sparda’s Tower stood on the beach — armed with turrets, guarded by vicious tames, a fortress carved from determination. Only then did I realize something, The man who spawned in as a Bob had arrived with strength already in him. Wisdom already in him, A survivor’s instinct that didn’t need teaching, And while we built, something else was happening. My father‑in‑law watched us, He watched the dinos, He watched the building, He watched the world come alive on the screen. A world with monsters, A world with Viking armor, A world where he whispered to himself, “I need to see more.” This was the beginning of something none of us understood yet. 
 The beginning of The Blind One.

The Day the Blind One Watched Where a Silent Witness Felt the Call of the Ark 
While Sparda and I built, fought, gathered, and survived, another presence lingered just behind us. He didn’t speak much, He didn’t interrupt, He didn’t ask questions, He simply watched. The glow of two screens lit the room — mine and Sparda’s — and in that glow stood the man who would one day become the Father of the Valley’s Heart. At first, I thought he was just curious, A passing interest, A moment of distraction after a long day. But there was something deeper in the way he watched. He didn’t look at the UI, He didn’t look at the menus, He looked at the world. The dinos, The forests, The mountains, The armor, The danger, The freedom, A world where a man could build again, A world where a man could fight again, A world where a man could belong again, He didn’t say it out loud, but the truth was already forming in his eyes, (I need to see more.)

The Spark That Ignited the Future 
One evening, I was watching Raasclark’s fight against Rockwell — the old ASE footage, the battle that had shaped so many survivors before us. He walked in, paused behind me, and asked, “What is that?” “That’s Rockwell,” I said.  “He ingested element. Now he’s a monster. Raas is trying to kill him.” He watched the screen with a focus I hadn’t seen in years. “That would be hard to fight,” he murmured. Then he added two words — quiet, almost lost under the sound of Rockwell’s roar, “One day.” I didn’t understand what he meant, Not then. But those two words were the first crack in the wall that had kept him away from games since the stroke that stole ninety percent of his vision, Those two words were the first heartbeat of a destiny none of us saw coming.

The Pull of a Forgotten World 
As days passed, he watched more closely, He watched Sparda build with precision, He watched me gather and craft, He watched the world shift from chaos to structure, from survival to purpose, And something inside him stirred, Not nostalgia, Not envy, Not longing, Recognition, He had been a gamer once — a warrior of the old worlds,  a veteran of the Xbox 360 era, a man who had fought through digital battlefields long before Ark ever existed. The stroke had taken his sight, Life had taken his momentum, But Ark… Ark offered something back, A world where vision wasn’t everything, A world where sound, instinct, and determination mattered more, A world where he could try, And he wanted to try.

The Day Destiny Knocked 
He didn’t announce it, He didn’t ask permission, He didn’t hesitate, He simply walked through the door one afternoon carrying a bag. Inside it was the future, A 75‑inch 4K smart TV — a screen large enough for a man with 10% vision to see the world again. An Xbox Series X — a machine powerful enough to carry him into the Ark. He placed the bag on the table and said, “I bought a new Xbox. Can someone set it up for me?” We didn’t understand the weight of that moment, Not yet. We set up the TV, We connected the console, We handed him the controller, And the world shifted. Because this was not the day a man bought a console, This was the day the Blind One stepped toward the Ark, This was the day the Valley’s heart began to beat.

The Island, 
Day 432 Where the Blind One Took His First Steps Into the Ark 
When the Island finished loading, the screen glowed bright across the room — a world waiting for a man who had not walked one in years.Sand beneath his feet, Waves rolling in, A parasaur calling in the distance. Wind whispering through the trees. For most survivors,  this is where the fear begins, For him, it was where life returned. He moved slowly at first — not because he was unsure, but because he was listening. Every sound mattered, Every vibration mattered, Every footstep was a map, He didn’t see the world the way we did, He felt it, And the Island, harsh as it was, welcomed him.

A Survivor Reborn 
He walked the shoreline with the careful confidence of someone who had fought battles long before Ark ever existed. He learned the rhythm of the world, The crunch of footsteps on sand, the rustle of trees when danger approached, the deep, distant roar of predators, the soft hum of crafting in his hands, He wasn’t just playing, He was returning. Returning to a part of himself the stroke had tried to take, Returning to the joy of discovery,  Returning to the fire of challenge, Returning to the warrior he had been, And the Island felt it,  A new presence, A new heartbeat, A new survivor whose determination outshone his sight.

Death Valley, you carried me through,
When I thought I was lost, I still had you.
Richard’s dream still burns in the skies,
Every sunrise in ARK is his eyes.
I searched the world for where I belong,
It was here with my tribe all along.

The Island Tested Him 
The Island does not care who you are. It does not care what you’ve survived, It tests everyone the same way, With hunger, With cold, With predators, With chaos, But he didn’t flinch. Every dilo that hissed at him, he faced, Every raptor that lunged, he heard before it struck, Every cliff he nearly walked off, he learned to avoid by instinct alone, He adapted faster than any of us expected. Not because he could see the world — but because he could feel it, And in that,  he was stronger than any of us.

The Birth of the Valley’s Heart 
This was not the day a man started a game, This was the day the Blind One entered the Ark, The day he reclaimed a world he thought he’d lost. The day he stepped into a land that would one day carry his legacy, The day the Valley gained the man who would become its emotional core. From this moment forward, the Codex changed, The Valley changed, We changed, Because the Blind One had arrived, And the Valley had found its heart.
Community Links
If you want this page shortened, split into separate tabs, or further edited, tell me and I will generate the exact replacement block.

Props.Title: Web Url Widget
Props.Note: The Url Widget makes it easy to host the JSON widget somewhere on the web and reuse it on multiple server or edit it without the need to joining the game.
